title: Learn SQL with Step-by-Step Visual Execution
subtitle2: Learn how to keep all rows from the left table even if no match exists.
cardcontent: Now a new department 'Sports' is added without a head assigned yet. Ananya wants to list all departments with their heads, even if some departments don’t have a head. LEFT JOIN helps!
codeComQuery:
-- LEFT JOIN example
SELECT d.department, d.head FROM departments d LEFT JOIN students s ON d.department = s.department GROUP BY d.department, d.head;
card2content: LEFT JOIN helps you fetch all records from the main table even when related data is missing. You'll understand how unmatched rows appear as NULL, how JOINs combine information across tables, and how SQL ensures no department is left out—even without a head assigned.

table1.title: Students Count by Department (Full List)
table1.word: Counts how many students belong to each department. The LEFT JOIN ensures 'Sports' is included, showing a count of 0.
table1.code:
SELECT d.department, COUNT(s.student_id) AS total_students
FROM departments d
LEFT JOIN students s
ON d.department = s.department
GROUP BY d.department;

table2.title: Department Heads Overview (Left Table)
table2.word: Shows each department and its assigned head. Notice that the new 'Sports' department has an assigned head 'Dr. Sanjay', but no students are linked.

table3.title: LEFT JOIN Output
table3.word: This output shows all departments (from the left table: `departments`). Since no students are in the 'Sports' department, the `student` columns would be NULL, but since we only selected `d.head`, the assigned head is shown.
table3.code: SELECT d.department, d.head FROM departments d LEFT JOIN students s ON d.department = s.department;

table4.title: Identifying Departments with No Students
table4.word: Identifies departments that have no matching records in the right table (`students`) by filtering for `NULL` values after the LEFT JOIN. This is a common pattern.
table4.code:
SELECT d.department
FROM departments d
LEFT JOIN students s
ON d.department = s.department
WHERE s.student_id IS NULL;

multicont.word1: All records from the left table are always included.
multicont.word2: Unmatched columns from the right table appear as NULL.
multicont.word3: Use `WHERE column IS NULL` after a LEFT JOIN to find unmatched records.
multicont.word4: The LEFT JOIN keyword can sometimes be written as LEFT OUTER JOIN.
